{{EngvarB|date=March 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2017}} {{Bahá'í sidebar}} The origins of the '''Bahá'í Faith in Bangladesh''' begin previous to its independence, when it was part of [[British Raj]]. The roots of the Bahá'í Faith in the region go back to the first days of the [[Bábí]] religion in 1844.{{cite web | title = The Bahá'í Faith -Brief History | work = Official Website of the National Spiritual Assembly of India | publisher = National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of India | year = 2003 | url = http://www.bahaindia.org/intro/history.html | doi = | accessdate = 4 April 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090414023126/http://bahaindia.org/intro/history.html| archivedate= 14 April 2009 | deadurl= no}} During [[Bahá'u'lláh]]'s lifetime, as founder of the religion, he encouraged some of his followers to move to India.{{cite web | last = Momen | first = Moojan|authorlink= Moojan Momen |author2=Smith, Peter | title = Bahá'í History | work = Draft A Short Encyclopedia of the Baha'i Faith | publisher = Bahá'í Library Online | url = http://bahai-library.com/encyclopedia_history | doi = | accessdate = 4 April 2009}} It may have been Jamál Effendi who was first sent and stopped in [[Dhaka]] more than once.{{cite journal | last = Momen | first = Moojan |authorlink= Moojan Momen | title = Jamál Effendi and the early spread of the Bahá'í Faith in Asia | journal = Baha'i Studies Review | volume = 09 | issue = 1999/2000 | pages = | publisher = Association for Baha'i Studies (English-Speaking Europe) | location = | year = 2000 | url = http://bahai-library.com/bsr/bsr09/9B2_momen_jamal.htm | issn = | accessdate = 4 April 2009 | postscript = .}} The first Bahá'ís in the area that would later become Bangladesh was when a Bengali group from Chittagong accepted the religion while in Burma.{{cite book |last=Ali |first=Meer Mobashsher |year=2012 |chapter=Bahai |chapter-url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Bahai |editor1-last=Islam |editor1-first=Sirajul |editor1-link=Sirajul Islam |editor2-last=Jamal |editor2-first=Ahmed A. |title=Banglapedia: National Encyclopedia of Bangladesh |edition=Second |publisher=[[Asiatic Society of Bangladesh]]}} By 1950 there were enough members of the religion to elect [[Local Spiritual Assembly|Local Spiritual Assemblies]] in [[Chittagong]] and [[Dacca]].{{cite web | url = http://bahai-library.com/handscause_statistics_1953-63&chapter=1 | title = The Bahá'í Faith: 1844–1963: Information Statistical and Comparative, Including the Achievements of the Ten Year International Bahá'í Teaching & Consolidation Plan 1953–1963| author = Compiled by [[Hands of the Cause]] Residing in the Holy Land | pages = 51, 107}} The community has contributed to the progress of the nation of Bangladesh individually and collectively and in 2005 the [[World Christian Encyclopedia]] estimated the Bahá'í population of Bangladesh about 10600.{{cite web| title = Most Baha'i Nations (2005) | work = QuickLists > Compare Nations > Religions > | publisher = The Association of Religion Data Archives | year = 2005| url =http://www.thearda.com/QuickLists/QuickList_40c.asp | accessdate = 4 July 2009}} ==Early period== The Bahá'í Faith in Bangladesh begins previous to its independence when it was part of British Raj. The roots of the Bahá'í Faith in the region go back to the first days of the [[Bábí]] religion in 1844. Four Babis are known from India in this earliest period; it is not known from what sub-region they came from, but at least some of them were known as [[Sufi]]s and some were termed [[Sayyid]].{{cite journal | last = Manuchehri | first = Sepehr | editor-last = Walbridge | editor-first = John | title = Historical Accounts of two Indian Babis: Sa'in Hindi and Sayyid Basir Hindi | journal = Research Notes in Shaykhi, Babi and Baha'i Studies | volume = 05 | issue = 02 | pages = | publisher = | location = | date = April 2001 | url = http://www.h-net.org/~bahai/notes/vol5/hunud.htm | issn = | accessdate = 4 April 2009 }} The first was [[Shaykh]] Sa'id Hindi, one of the [[Letters of the Living]], who was from somewhere in what was then India.{{cite journal | last = Manuchehri | first = Sepehr | editor-last = Walbridge | editor-first = John | title = The Practice of Taqiyyah (Dissimulation) in the Babi and Bahai Religions| journal = Research Notes in Shaykhi, Babi and Baha'i Studies| volume = 03| issue = 03| pages = | publisher = | location = | date = September 1999 | url =http://www.h-net.msu.edu/~bahai/notes/vol3/taqiya.htm | issn = | accessdate = 4 April 2009 | postscript = .}} Four other Indians were listed among the 318 Bábís who fought at the [[Battle of Fort Tabarsi]]. ===Early Bahá'í period=== During [[Bahá'u'lláh]]'s lifetime, as founder of the religion, he encouraged some of his followers to move to India. In 1878, a Bahá'í moved through Chittagong and Dhaka, passing through on his way to [[Burma]] from [[Calcutta]]. This may have been [[Jamál Effendi]], an early Bahá'í who travelled there. Regardless it is clear that Effendi undertook a second trip to south-east Asia in about 1884-5. Effendi was asked to return to the region by [[Bahá'u'lláh]] and this time accompanied by Sayyid Mustafá. They set off for India and eventually stopped in Dhaka, the capital of [[Bangladesh]] where they met some people including a professor of Arabic at [[Dhaka College]]. Much later, around 1891, Jamál Effendi was confused with a terrorist and reported on by British agents among the Indian population, as confirmed by records found in the Indian government's national archives. Following the passing of Bahá'u'lláh, as the leadership of the religion fell to [['Abdu'l-Bahá]], he in turn sent further representatives in his stead – both Persian and American.{{cite journal | last = Garlington | first = William | editor-last = R.I. Cole | editor-first = Juan | editor2-last = Maneck. | editor2-first = Susan | title = The Baha'i Faith in India: A Developmental Stage Approach | journal = Occasional Papers in Shaykhi, Babi and Baha'i Studies | volume = June, 1997 | issue = 02 | pages = | publisher = Humanities & Social Sciences Online | location = | year = 1997 | url = http://www.h-net.org/~bahai/bhpapers/india1.htm | issn = | accessdate = 4 April 2009 | postscript = .}} As early as 1910 the national community in India/Burma was urged to visibly distinguish itself from Islam by Bahá'í institutions of America.{{Cite news | title = Letter from the House of Spirituality of Bahais, Chicago, Ill., U. S. A. to the Assembly of Rangoon Burma | periodical = Star of the West | volume = 01 | issue = 11 | pages = | date =10 February 1910 | url = http://bahai-library.com/abdulbaha_star_west_1&chapter=11 | postscript = .}} Nationally coordinated activities began and reached a peak in December 1920, with the first All-India Bahá'í Convention, held in Bombay for three days. Representatives from India's major religious communities were present as well as Bahá'í delegates from throughout the country. ===Middle period=== In 1923, still as part of India, a regional [[National Spiritual Assembly]] was formed for India and Burma which then included the area now part of Bangladesh as well as Pakistan.{{cite web| last = Hassall | first = Graham | title = Notes on Research on National Spiritual Assemblies | work = Research notes | publisher = Asia Pacific Bahá'í Studies | url =http://bahai-library.com/hassall_nsas_years_formation | doi =| accessdate = 21 December 2008}} However the first Bahá'ís in the area that would later become Bangladesh was when a Bengali group from Chittagong accepted the religion while they were in Burma. In 1937, [[John Esslemont]]'s ''Bahá'u'lláh and the New Era'' was translated and published in [[Bengali language|Bengali]] (Baha'u'llah o nab zug) in Chittagong under the authority of the National Spiritual Assembly of India and Burma.{{cite web | last = Bahá'í International Community | first = | authorlink = Bahá'í International Community | title = "Bahá'u'lláh and the New Era" editions and printings held in Bahá'í World Centre Library Decade by decade 1920 -2000+ | work = General Collections | publisher = International Bahá'í Library | url = http://library.bahai.org/gc/bne.html | doi = | accessdate = 4 April 2009}} In 1941, [[Enoch Olinga]], later a prominent Bahá'í, was stationed in what was then [[East Pakistan]] as a member of the British military before he left the military and became a member of the religion.{{cite web | last = Francis | first = Richard | title = Enoch Olinga Hand of the Cause of God Father of Victories | work = Collected Biographies | publisher = Bahá'í Library Online | year = 1998 | url =http://bahai-library.com/francis_olinga_biography | accessdate = 4 April 2009}} By 1950 there were enough members of the religion to begin setting up administrative bodies. These were Bahá'í [[Local Spiritual Assembly|Local Spiritual Assemblies]] and they were elected in [[Chittagong]] and [[Dacca]]. With independence as part of Pakistan in 1958, East and West Pakistan elected a separate national assembly from India.{{Cite book | title = In Memoriam | journal = The Bahá'í World | volume = XVIII | publisher = Bahá'í World Centre | pages = 795–797 | year = 1986 | url = http://bahai-library.com/books/bw18/773-800.html | isbn = 0-85398-234-1 | author = Universal House of Justice}} In 1959 Muhammad Mustafa travelled to [[Bahá'í Faith in Liberia|Liberia]] and was commissioned to address some Muslim concerns about the Bahá'í Faith. This was ultimately published as ''Baha'u'llah: The Great Announcement of the Qur'an'' through the Bangladesh Bahá'í Publishing Trust.{{cite book | last = Mustafa | first = Muhammad |translator-last=Mustafa |translator-first=Rowshan |editor1-last=Herzog |editor1-first=Laura M. | title = Baha'u'llah: The Great Announcement of the Qur'an | publisher = Baha'i Publishing Trust | location = Dhaka, Bangladesh | pages = Foreword and p. 112 "About the Author" | nopp = yes | url =http://bahai-library.com/mustafa_bahaullah_announcement_quran | isbn = }} In 1960 there was a Teaching Conference of East Pakistan, at Dhaka.{{cite book | last = Universal House of Justice | first = | authorlink = Universal House of Justice | title = The Ministry of the Custodians 1957–1963: An Account of the Stewardship of the Hands of the Cause | publisher = Universal House of Justice | year = 1992 | location = Great Britain | pages = | url = http://bahai-library.com/uhj_ministry_custodians&chapter=4 | isbn = 0-85398-350-X}} By 1963 there was an additional local assembly in [[Mymensingh]] and smaller groups between 1 and 9 adults in [[Jamalpur District|Jamalpur]] and [[Mirpur Thana|Mirpur]]. Following the independence of Bangladesh in 1971, the national assembly of Bangladesh was also separately elected in 1971. 10 years later the national convention had 61 delegates.{{cite journal | title = Around the World; Bangladesh | journal = Bahá'í News |date=June 1981 | issue = 603 |issn=0195-9212 | page = 16 | url = | postscript = .}} In 1974 [[Rúhíyyih Khanum]] visited the country, even to meeting with President [[Mohammad Ullah]].{{cite journal | title =Amatu'l-Baha in the Far East | journal = Bahá'í News |date=August 1974 | issue = 521 | pages = 5–7 | url = | postscript =.}} In 1984 ''The Baha'i Fund: A Time for Sacrifice'' was published by the National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of Bangladesh.{{cite web | last = MacEoin | first = Denis |author2= William Collins | title = Anti-Baha'i Polemics | work = The Babi and Baha'i Religions: An Annotated Bibliography | publisher = Greenwood Press's ongoing series of Bibliographies and Indexes in Religious Studies | url =http://bahai-library.com/books/biblio/financial.html | accessdate = 4 April 2009 |at = Entry #1}} ==In more recent times== In 1996 the [[Universal House of Justice]] commented:{{cite web | last = Universal House of Justice | first = | authorlink = Universal House of Justice | title = Ridvan Letter to South Asia | work = Published by the Universal House of Justice | publisher = Bahá'í Library Online | date = April 1996 | url = http://bahai-library.com/uhj_ridvan_1996_southasia | accessdate = 4 April 2009}}
"The Bahá'í community of Bangladesh, flourishing in the midst of a Muslim society, is a source of joy to the entire Bahá'í world. In recent years and with astonishing rapidity, that community began to achieve extraordinary success in the teaching field, and throughout the Three Year Plan it has sustained consistently large-scale expansion. Its institutions have demonstrated their capacity to mobilize the human resources at their disposal, and those who have responded to the call for action have sacrificially and with the utmost devotion spread the Divine Teachings among the Muslim, Hindu and tribal populations of that country. The purity of their motives and the sincerity of their efforts to address the needs of society have won them recognition from government officials in the highest circles. Their exertions to promote love and unity among the majority Muslim and minority Hindu populations are bearing increasing fruit, a striking testimony to the potency of Bahá'u'lláh's Revelation."
==Modern community== In Bangladesh the Bahá'ís have had the right to hold their public meetings, establish academic centres, teach their faith, and elect their administrative councils.{{cite web | last = Wardany | first = Youssef | title = The Right of Belief in Egypt: Case study of Baha’i minority | work = | publisher = Al Waref Institute | year = 2009 | url = http://www.alwaref.org/en/accueil/39-human-rights/89-the-right-of-belief-in-egypt-case-study-of-bahai-minority | accessdate = 4 April 2009 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090315233147/http://alwaref.org/en/accueil/39-human-rights/89-the-right-of-belief-in-egypt-case-study-of-bahai-minority | archivedate = 15 March 2009 | deadurl = yes | df = dmy-all }} However the government of Bangladesh voted against the United Nations resolution ''Situation of Human Rights in the Islamic Republic of Iran'' on 19 December 2001 raised in response to the [[Persecution of Bahá'ís]] in Iran.{{cite web | last = Bahá'í International Community | first = | authorlink = Bahá'í International Community | title = UN General Assembly Resolution 2001 | work = | publisher = Bahá'í International Community | year = 2008 | url =http://info.bahai.org/article-1-8-3-23.html | doi = | accessdate = 4 April 2009}} Regardless, Bahá'ís in Bangladesh have been able to co-ordinate and act in groups. About 150 gathered for a summer school in 1977{{cite journal | title = Bangladesh | journal = Bahá'í News |date=February 1978 | issue = 563 | page = 17 | url = | postscript = .}} and about 300 attended the winter school held February 1978.{{cite journal | title = Around the World; Bangladesh | journal = Bahá'í News |date=June 1978 | issue = 567 | page = 13 | url = | postscript = .}} Zena Sorabjee of the [[Bahá'í International Community]], shared a platform with [[Pope John Paul II]] during his visit to India in 1999 and the meeting was aired through satellite television. It is reported that Bahá'ís in a number of countries, including Bangladesh, viewed the broadcast.{{cite web | last = Universal House of Justice| first = | authorlink = Universal House of Justice | title = Report of the inter-religious meeting held in New Delhi on 7 November 1999 on the occasion of the visit to India of Pope John Paul II | work = Letters from the Universal House of Justice | publisher = Universal House of Justice | date = 12 December 1999 | url = http://bahai-library.com/uhj_dialogue_new_delhi| doi = | accessdate = 4 April 2009}} In 2008 about 30 out of 200 Bahá'ís managed to get passports and visas and travel from Bangladesh to a regional conference called for by the Universal House of Justice in Kolkata, India, although many more of their fellow believers weren't able to make the trip. The Bahá'ís went in groups to request their travel documents, with many of them waiting up to three days even to reach the door. In the end, most were turned away without the visa.{{Cite news | last = Bahá'í International Community | first = | author-link = Bahá'í International Community | title = The Kolkata Regional Conference | newspaper = Bahá'í World News Service | pages = | date = 23 November 2008 | url =http://news.bahai.org/community-news/regional-conferences/kolkata.html | postscript = .}} Since its inception the religion has had involvement in [[socio-economic development]] beginning by giving greater freedom to women,{{cite web | last = Momen | first = Moojan |authorlink= Moojan Momen | title = History of the Baha'i Faith in Iran | work = draft "A Short Encyclopedia of the Baha'i Faith" | publisher = Bahai-library.com | url =http://bahai-library.com/momen_encyclopedia_iran#9.%20Social%20and%20economic%20development | doi = | accessdate = 16 October 2009}} promulgating the promotion of female education as a priority concern,{{cite journal | last = Kingdon | first = Geeta Gandhi | title = Education of women and socio-economic development | journal = Baha'i Studies Review | volume = 7 | issue = 1 | year = 1997 | url = http://bahai-library.com/kingdon_education_women_development | postscript = . }} and that involvement was given practical expression by creating schools, agricultural coops, and clinics. The religion entered a new phase of activity when a message of the [[Universal House of Justice]] dated 20 October 1983 was released.{{cite journal |title= The Baha'i Faith 1957–1988: A Survey of Contemporary Developments | first = Moojan | last = Momen |author2=Smith, Peter | year = 1989 | url = http://bahai-library.com/momen_smith_developments_1957-1988 |volume = 19 | journal = Religion |issue= 1 | pages=63–91 |doi= 10.1016/0048-721X(89)90077-8 |postscript= .}} Bahá'ís were urged to seek out ways, compatible with the [[Bahá'í teachings]], in which they could become involved in the social and economic development of the communities in which they lived. Worldwide in 1979 there were 129 officially recognised Bahá'í socio-economic development projects. For the [[International Year of the Child]] Bangladesh Bahá'ís established tutorial schools in three villages.{{cite journal | title = Bangladesh | journal = Bahá'í News |date=July 1980 | issue = 592 | page = 16 | url = | postscript = .}} By 1987, the number of officially recognised development projects had increased to 1482. The Bahá'ís in Bangladesh work to promote their interests and contributions to Bangladesh. Even early on there were village level schools run by the local assembly in the [[Jessore]] area.{{cite journal | title = Bangladesh | journal = Bahá'í News |date=November 1978 | issue = 572 | page = 16 | url = | postscript = .}} In 1981 the second Bangladesh National Baha'i Women's Conference took place attracting Bahá'í women from Bangladesh, India, Iran, Malaysia and Italy.{{cite journal | title = Around the World; Bangladesh | journal = Bahá'í News |date=June 1981 | issue = 603 | page = 12 | url = | postscript = .}} In 1995 three national newspapers published articles on a public meeting sponsored by the local spiritual assembly of [[Khulna]] to mark the founding of the United Nations. Tents on the grounds of the Bahá'í Center there were filled with 50 Bahá'ís and 200 guests who listened to speeches and then enjoyed the performance of songs written by Bahá'í youth on the theme of unity and amity among the nations and races of the earth.{{cite web | last = Bahá'í International Community | first = | authorlink = Bahá'í International Community | title = UN 50: Bahá'ís Commemorate the Fiftieth Anniversary of the United Nations | publisher = Bahá'í International Community | year = 1996 | url =http://info.bahai.org/article-1-9-2-13.html | doi = | accessdate = 4 April 2009}} Some of the students of the New Era Development Institute, an educational NGO in India run by the Bahá'ís, have come from the Bangladesh Bahá'í community in 1997.{{cite web | last = Bahá'í International Community | first = | authorlink = Bahá'í International Community | title = New Era Development Institute – In India, a new approach to vocational education | publisher = Bahá'í International Community | date = October–December 1997 | url = http://info.bahai.org/article-1-8-1-13.html | doi = | accessdate = 4 April 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090421122444/http://info.bahai.org/article-1-8-1-13.html| archivedate= 21 April 2009 | deadurl= no}} In 1988 Bahá'í doctors setup free treatment camps.{{cite journal | title = The World; Bangladesh | journal = Bahá'í News |date=September 1988 | issue = 690 |issn=0195-9212 | page = 14 | url = | postscript = .}} In addition to work in groups, some individuals have become well known for their contributions to Bangladesh society. Bahá'í [[Samarendra Nath Goswami]], is well known in Bangladesh as Secretary General of the [[Bangladesh Minority Lawyers Association]]{{Cite news | last = Benkin | first = Dr. Richard L. | title = Bangladesh to Frame Sedition Charge against Salah Uddin Shoaib Choudhury | newspaper = The Asian Tribune | pages = | date = 19 May 2006 | url =http://www.asiantribune.com/index.php?q=node/157 | postscript = .}} and senior advocate of [[Bangladesh Supreme Court]] and contributed to founding a law journal and two law schools.{{cite web | title = History of Founder Members | work = Official Website of the Bangladesh Minority Lawyer's Association | publisher = Bangladesh Minority Lawyer's Association | year = 2007 | url = http://www.minoritylawyer.org/founder.html | doi = | accessdate = 4 April 2009 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080617015859/http://www.minoritylawyer.org/founder.html |archivedate = 17 June 2008}} In 1994, he edited ''The Principles of Bahá'í Personal Law'' which was published by the [[Bangladesh Law Times]].{{Cite book |editor = Samarendra Nath Goswami, LL.M |year = 1994 |title = Principles of Bahá'í Personal Law, The |publisher = Bangladesh Law Times |location = Dhaka, Bangladesh |ol = 24280885M}} In the early 1990s, Baha'i law was included in the law curriculum of [[Dhaka University]].Bahá'í World Centre. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=R1UlAQAAIAAJ The Bahá'í world 1994–95: an international record]''. 1996. [[Payam Akhavan]], Bahá'í and a renowned human rights lawyer represented [[Sheikh Hasina]] (a once and again Prime Minister of Bangladesh).{{cite web|last=Incidental Blogger |first= |title=Hospitality, Dhaka Style: Akhavan, Sloan and Another |work= |publisher= |date=4 March 2008 |url=http://www.wordsandbites.com/2008/03/hospitality-dhaka-style-akhavan-sloan-and-another/ |accessdate=4 April 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081121184828/http://www.wordsandbites.com/2008/03/hospitality-dhaka-style-akhavan-sloan-and-another/ |archivedate=21 November 2008 |df= }}{{cite web | last = Hosseini | first = Fazel | title = War Crimes Prosecutor Payam Akhavan Speaks about his Global Fight for Human Rights – Interview With Payam Akhavan (Part One) | work = | publisher = Gozaar, Freedom House | date = 1 December 2006 | url = http://www.gozaar.org/english/interview-en/Global-Fight-for-Human-Rights1.html | accessdate = 4 April 2009}}{{cite web | last = Hosseini | first = Fazel | title = War Crimes Prosecutor Payam Akhavan Speaks about his Global Fight for Human Rights – Interview With Payam Akhavan (Part Two) | work = | publisher = Gozaar, Freedom House | date = 1 January 2007 | url = http://www.gozaar.org/english/interview-en/Global-Fight-for-Human-Rights.html | accessdate = 4 April 2009}} The Bahá'ís of Bangladesh have participated in various efforts affecting society in Bangladesh. Representatives of the Bahá'ís of Bangladesh were among those present for a 19 December 2003 conference entitled "Education: The Right of Every Girl and Boy," which was organised by the [[Bahá'í International Community]] with the support of the United Nations Children's Fund ([[UNICEF]]) and the government of Bangladesh among other institutions.{{Cite news | last = Bahá'í International Community | first = | author-link = Bahá'í International Community | title = Girl highlights conference theme | newspaper = Bahá'í World News Service | pages = | date = 19 December 2003 | url =http://news.bahai.org/story/269 }} Representatives of the Bahá'í International Community were among the speakers at the "Conference on Interfaith Cooperation for Peace," which was held on 22 June 2005 with the government of Bangladesh among the co-sponsors.{{Cite news | last = Bahá'í International Community | first = | author-link = Bahá'í International Community | title = Unity stressed at interfaith conference | newspaper = Bahá'í World News Service | pages = | date = 28 June 2005 | url = http://news.bahai.org/story/379 | postscript = .}} In September 2002, a slide show on preventing the spread of [[Dengue]] fever was presented at the National Bahá'í Center in Shantinagar.{{cite web | last = Ahamed | first = Khaja | title = Dengue Slide Show | work = Official Bangladesh Dengue Website | publisher = Bangladesh Dengue Website | year = 2002 | url = http://www.geocities.com/prevent_dengue/slideshow.html | doi = | accessdate = 4 April 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091025024334/http://geocities.com/prevent_dengue/slideshow.html|archivedate=25 October 2009}} December 2007, the [[Centre for Advance Research in Humanities]] of [[Dhaka University]] organised a seminar on "The Baha'i Faith and World Peace" at the lecture theatre of the university presided over by Prof Kazi Nazrul Islam,(not the [[Kazi Nazrul Islam|famous Bengali individual of the same name]] who died in 1977) Director of the centre. Mazhgan Bahar, Professor of English Department of [[American International University-Bangladesh]], presented the keynote paper at the seminar, while Prof Dr Rawshan Ara of Philosophy Department, Prof Shahid Hussain, Secretary General of [[International Association for Religious Freedom]] and Prof Jahangir Alam of the world religion Department, among others, were present.{{Cite news | last = DU Correspondent | title = Inter-faith accord to promote world peace stressed | newspaper = The New Nation, Bangladesh's Independent News Source | pages = | date = 3 December 2007 | url =http://nation.ittefaq.com/issues/2007/12/03/all0101.htm}} ===Demographics=== It is not known how many organised communities of Bahá'ís there are in Bangladesh. In 2005 the [[World Christian Encyclopedia]] estimated the Bahá'í population of Bangladesh at about 10600. There are reports of many conversions from November 1988 to September 1989 including many [[Munda people|Munda]] and [[Languages of Bangladesh#Regional and tribal languages|Arakan people]].{{cite journal | title = The World; Bangladesh | journal = Bahá'í News |date=January 1990 | issue = 705 | issn=0195-9212 | page = 14 | url =}} ==See also== * [[History of Bangladesh]] * [[Religion in Bangladesh]] * [[Bahá'í Faith in India]] * [[Bahá'í Faith in Pakistan]] ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==Further reading== * Alam, Muhammad Jahangir (2011). ''Bahai Religious Faith and Tradition in Bangladesh''. Bangladesh e-Journal of Sociology, 8:1, pages 87–92. * [http://bahai-library.com/locations/Bangladesh Chronology and related documents on Bahá’í Library Online] {{Religion in Bangladesh}} {{Asia topic|Bahá'í Faith in}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Baha'i Faith In Bangladesh}} [[Category:Religion in Bangladesh]] [[Category:Bahá'í Faith by country|Bangladesh]] {{Religion in Bangladesh topics}}

{{Bahá'í sidebar}} '''Bahá'í marriage''' is union of a man and a woman. Its purpose is mainly spiritual and is to foster harmony, fellowship and unity between the two partners.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Kitáb-i-Aqdas|page=42|url=http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/b/KA/ka-5.html}}</ref> The [[Bahá'í Faith|Bahá'í]] teachings on [[marriage]] call it a ''fortress for well-being and salvation'' and place marriage and the family as the foundation of the structure of [[society|human society]].<ref>{{cite book|title=The Kitáb-i-Aqdas|page=205|url=http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/b/KA/ka-105.html}}</ref>
== Spiritual nature ==
The Bahá'í teachings on marriage see it as an eternal bond that survives past the lives of the partners in the physical life, and into the [[Bahá'í cosmology|spiritual worlds]]. Thus the teachings stress that during courting the partners must take the utmost care to become acquainted with each other's character. Furthermore, the husband and wife should be united not only physically, but also spiritually, so that they can improve the spiritual life of each other, and that they can spiritually advance towards God.<ref>{{cite book|title=Lights of Guidance|page=369|url=http://bahai-library.com/hornby_lights_guidance_2&chapter=2|editor=Helen Hornby}}</ref>
== Engagement ==
The [[Parenting|parents]] cannot interfere with the selection of the person their child wants to get married to, but marriage has been conditioned, once the couple’s wish is known, upon the permission of their parents.<ref name="Abdu'l-Bahá: Selections from the Writings of Abdu'l-Bahá, p. 118">{{cite book|title=Lights of Guidance|page=376|url=http://bahai-library.com/hornby_lights_guidance_2&chapter=2}}</ref> The purpose of this law is to foster unity between the two families, since the Bahá'í teachings see marriage and the family as the foundation of the structure and society, and having disunity between two families is not conducive to that. The consent of all parents is needed even if one of the partners is not a Bahá'í.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Kitáb-i-Aqdas|page=207|url=http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/b/KA/ka-109.html}}</ref>
Bahá'ís{{who|date=December 2017}} see this aspect of Bahá'í marriage as combining marriages practices from the East and West;{{Citation needed|date=July 2011}} in the East arranged marriage is common, and in the west marriages sometimes go forward with no input from the parents. The Bahá'í marriage gives full freedom of the individuals to select their partner, but places certain gratitude and respect to the parents.
:"A couple should study each other's character and spend time getting to know each other before they decide to marry, and when they do marry it should be with the intention of establishing an eternal bond." <ref>The Universal House of Justice. ''Baha'i Marriage and Family Life''. November 2, 1982, p. 20.</ref>
===Waiting period=== The time between the official public announcement of the marriage and the wedding ceremony should not exceed 95 days.<ref>{{cite web|title=Bahá’u’lláh’s Marriage Law|url=http://www.bahaimarriage.net/Baha'iMarriageLaws-BahaiCanadaExcerpt-Feb2011.pdf|pages=37–38|date=January–February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=The Kitáb-i-Aqdas|page=120|url=http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/b/KA/ka-15.html}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|script-title=fa:گنجينه حدود و احكام|pages=166|url=http://reference.bahai.org/fa/t/c/|language=Persian}}</ref> The 95-day period of engagement is currently applicable only to Persian believers.<ref>National Spiritual Assembly of the Baha'is of the United States. "[https://www.scribd.com/doc/279529/NSA-USA-Developing-Distinctive-Bahai-Communities Developing Distinctive Baha'i Communities]". Office of Assembly Development, Evanston, Illinois, 1998, p. 371.</ref>
== Ceremony ==
The Bahá'í marriage ceremony is done differently in each culture. The only compulsory part of the wedding is the reading of the wedding vows prescribed by [[Bahá'u'lláh]] which both the groom and the bride recite:
:''We will all, verily, abide by the Will of God.'' <ref>Bahá'u'lláh. [http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/b/KA/ka-15.html#gr6 The Kitáb-i-Aqdas: The Most Holy Book]. Bahá'í Publishing Trust, 1873, p. 105.</ref>
in the presence of two witnesses to be recorded through a Bahá'í [[Local Spiritual Assembly]]. Legal recognition depends on the civil laws of the country.
Most Bahá'í marriage ceremonies consist of the reading of Bahá'í writings, prayers and music followed by a talk about the spiritual nature of Bahá'í marriage, and then the reading of the vows.
== Laws ==
There are a number of laws that concern Bahá'í marriage
*Marriage is not obligatory, but is highly recommended.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Kitáb-i-Aqdas|page=149|url=http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/b/KA/ka-17.html}}</ref> *Marriage is defined between a man and a woman (see [[Homosexuality and Bahá'í Faith]]). *Only married couples may engage in sexual activity. *Both partners must be at least 15 years of age at the time of engagement. (The civil laws of their country must be obeyed) *Marriage is conditional on the consent of both parties and their parents.<ref name="The Kitáb-i-Aqdas">{{cite book|title=The Kitáb-i-Aqdas|page=150|url=http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/b/KA/ka-17.html}}</ref> *Marriage with non-Bahá'ís is permitted<ref name="The Kitáb-i-Aqdas"/> (see [[Interreligious marriage#Bahá'í Faith|Interreligious marriage]]). *The period of engagement must not exceed ninety-five days.<ref name="The Kitáb-i-Aqdas"/> (Not currently universally applicable) *A marriage should condition a payment of a dowry. The payment, if the husband lives in a city, is nineteen [http://bahai-library.com/writings/bahaullah/aqdas/glossary.html#Mithqal mithqáls] (approx. 2.22 troy ounces) of pure gold, and if the husband lives in a village the same amount in silver. However, it is preferable to content oneself with the lowest level that is nineteen mithqáls of silver for both city and village dwellers.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Kitáb-i-Aqdas|page=209|url=http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/b/KA/ka-112.html}}</ref> Bahá'u'lláh also set a maximum permitted dowry amount of 95 mithqáls (approx. 11.1 troy ounces). (Not currently universally applicable)<ref>{{cite web|title=Laws from the Kitab-i-Aqdas Not Yet Binding|url=http://bahai-library.com/uhj_laws_not_binding|author=Universal House of Justice}}</ref>
==Children and parenting==
Following the natural and appropriate extension of the union of marriage, children, whether adopted or biological, should be raised in this same spiritual atmosphere. Formal duties exist between parents and children (of education and obedience, training and respect.) Second to discovering God for oneself is respect for one's parents. Reversing the degradation of women and children is a subject of much attention in the Bahá'í Faith.
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
== References ==
*{{cite book |author=`Abdu'l-Bahá |authorlink=`Abdu'l-Bahá |year=1911 |title=`Abdu'l-Bahá in London |publisher=Bahá'í Publishing Trust: 1982 |location=London, UK |isbn=0-900125-50-0 |url=http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/ab/ABL/ }}
*{{cite book |author=Bahá'u'lláh |authorlink=Bahá'u'lláh |year=1873 |title=The Kitáb-i-Aqdas: The Most Holy Book |publisher=Bahá'í Publishing Trust |location=Wilmette, Illinois, USA |isbn=0-85398-999-0 |url=http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/b/KA/ }}
*{{cite book |author=Universal House of Justice |authorlink=Universal House of Justice |year=2001 |title=Letter: Applicability of the Laws and Ordinances of the Kitáb-i-Aqdas |publisher=The Bahá'í World Centre Department of the Secretariat |location=Haifa, Israel |id= |url=http://bahai-library.com/uhj_applicability_laws_aqdas }} * [http://bahai-library.com/uhj_relationship_husband_wife Relationship between Husband and Wife] by the [[Universal House of Justice]], 1980. * [http://bahai-library.com/uhj_violence_against_women Violence Against Women and Children] by Universal House of Justice, 1993. * [http://bahai-library.com/nolley_bahai_population_india Notes on Bahá'í population in India] by Charles Nolley and William Garlington, 1997.
==External links== * [http://www.bahai.org/action/family-life-children/family-life Bahai.org: Family Life and Children]

John (Baptist) '''Canut of Bon''' Gil ([[Valencia]], September 30, 1846 - [[Santiago]], November 9, 1896) was a [[Spanish people|Spanish]] preacher, best known for spreading his Protestant faith and founding evangelical churches in [[Chile]] during the [[19th century|nineteenth century]].
== Background == At age 18, John Canut of Bon entered the [[Society of Jesus]] in [[Balaguer|Balaguer, Leida]]. It is likely that he was of low socioeconomic status and was in training to become a [[tailor]]. After two years of training, he declared his religious vows and was sent to the [[Jesuit college|Jesuit College]] of [[Tortosa]] by the tailor shop he was working at.
The political situation in [[Spain]] at the time ([[Carlist Wars]] between clergy and laity) made it difficult for Canut of Bon to stay in the country, so he was reassigned to [[Argentina]] where he learned [[homeopathy]]. He later moved to [[Chile]] and then retired from the [[Society of Jesus|Jesuit Order]] in 1871, not because he lost his Catholic faith, but because he wanted to study. In 1872, he settled in [[Andes|The Andes]] where he devoted himself to the sale of fabrics and continued to work as a tailor. In August 5 of that year, he married Virginia Aguilar Robles, with whom he had three children.
In December 1876, he found a copy of the [[New Testament]] on a platform of a railway station in [[Quillota]] from the Bible Society of [[Valparaíso|Valparaiso]]. He defined this episode as the first meeting he had with the [[Gospel]].In 1880, he had the opportunity to meet a [[Presbyterianism|Presbyterian]] preacher named Robert MacLean, with whom he became friends. Canut of Bon then went on to become the first Spanish-speaking preacher in Chile.
His preaching in a country that was mostly [[Catholicism|Catholic]] led him to become a sort of outcast amongst from the foreign Presbyterians who feared deportation from Chile for violating the rules contained in the Constitution of 1833, which gave priority to the Official State Church over other religions. Canut of Bon was soon expelled for his new religion.
He asked for a reinstatement to the [[Catholic Church]] in 1884 in [[Curicó|Curico]]. However, his "Catholic Period" came to an end in 1888, when he met an [[Americans|American]] [[Methodism|Methodist]] pastor named [[William Taylor (bishop)|William Taylor]] (1821-1902) who preached in [[Africa]] and [[India]] between 1856 and 1883. In 1890, Canut of Bon was consecrated as bishop of the Methodist faith. His way of preaching, which was spirited and filled with knowledge, attracted many. However, this also meant that many enemies and his previous clients abandoned him. Despite this, he began to preach full-time, relying on his knowledge in the field of homeopathy to stay in the area. To avoid rejection from the [[Catholic priests]], he enlarged his preaching territory to southern cities and places where the Catholic Church had much less of an influence. For five years, he preached the Gospel and founded churches in [[Coquimbo Region|Coquimbo]], [[La Serena, Chile|La Serena]], [[Concepción, Chile|Concepcion]], [[Traiguén|Traiguen]], [[Angol]], Los Angeles, Victoria, and [[Temuco]].
Unfortunately, in 1896, he had to move to [[Santiago]] for health reasons where he died on November 9. His remains rest in the Patio of Dissenters of the General Cemetery of Santiago.
== Legacies == In the context of secular struggles caused by the non-separation of church and state, his style of street preaching caused him persecution and ridicule, but also a group of followers who decided to call themselves "Canutos," or "Followers of Canut." In the early [[20th century|twentieth century]], a writer and anarchist, Jose Santos Gonzalez Verades, described police offers arresting a group of evangelicals preaching and singing their way into prison, proclaiming themselves to be Canutos. Although this term has been extended to all members of [[Evangelicalism|evangelical churches]], whether of not they are followers of Canut of Bon, on occasion, the term is used to refer to any very religious person who effusively professes his or her religion in public. Some sectors of the evangelical cult reject this nickname and consider it burlesque, but it is accepted by the vast majority of evangelicals.
== See also == * [[Religion in Chile]] * [[Juan Canut de Bon]]
